sourceDesc.p: ST JOHN'S COLLEGE LIBRARY COLLECTION OWNED LETTERS FROM ROBERT (1895-1985) AND BERYL (1915- ) GRAVES TO WILLIAM GRAVES (1940- )

body.p: Thanks very much for the longest letter by at least five pages you have ever written home; I hate the thought of the alternative methods of death you have to choose on those glaciers, but I know you have a bias in favour of life.

I hope you got money I sent you Poste Restante at Linthal. Lombard Odier are prepared to send you up to £100 in Swiss francs whenever you call on them. In case you have lost their address at Corraterie 11, Geneva.
Deya is more hectic than ever. We have only Juan & Tomás here, Debbie is with the Foggs at Emmi's house(x), Lucia is away in Palma meeting the right sort of boy friend.

Our frigidaire came. We pulled down most of the larder to stick it in; where the broom cupboard used to be. It went like a charm for two days but has seized up owing to carbonized wicks from the stinking petroleo we get here. Just charring off the wick evenly in the hope we can get it alight again.

Hot weather. Old Gardener. The Reeves all arrived, but no Antonia of the Puig to look after them and no substitute. Caroleena had an exploratory operation to see if she had cancer - fortunately not -Mary Reid borrowed her house (being expelled from the Posada by the Reeves) & gave a 1st birthday party for Jasper. Everyone was there including two marvellous Israeli singers. In the middle of the feast there was a sharp angry explosion from the table where I wasn't: Frank insulting Esteban who wanted to kill him in consequence. Fortunately the Señora de Canellun quickly tugged at Esteban's sleeve and changed places with him, so parted the two. A quarrel about Abstract Painting & about that dim gipsy pansy Viola who was at the party and who gives me & Beryl and Esteban the creeps, but to others is tops.

Alan Lomax came of course the day after you left, with Shirley Collins who sings at the Troubadour and remembers you; it was terrific; & Po & Pedro sang Sa Ximbomba. We also heard a tape of the play; unfortunately part of the record got super-impressed on another part; but a lot survived including half of your superb talking blues & Lucia's song about the Wetbacks and the Rio and Cropton House and all the bangs. The night you left, Margot said she wanted to get out of Can Quet, so we asked Ricardo to lend her Sa Guarda, which he did. Apparently he had also lent it to Kitty, who arrives tonight. Fortunately Margot & Kitty are close friends, so there'll be no lio

Tom Sanders got a sudden phosphorous flame from a match & thought he had won 25,000 pesetas; but alas it was only a 25 peseta prize (red
flame instead of green). Alastair and I really think that the White Goddess film is coming off. We saw the Mati film which had some terrific moments; Brad was remarkable as a cad-comedian; Kate enchanting, and Margot even better when photographed than in three dimensions. Beryl says she ought to star as the White Goddess; but that will be hard to force on William Morris, who may want some ghastly Sofia Loren or someone. The melons are ripe and yellow and taste like heaven. The sea is calm. We have no more water troubles. Tomorrow I shall go into Palma & get the address you need.
body.note: Can Cabello, Deya; or C/o us.
Forgets you were there! love Mother

William spent six weeks in the Alps doing geological field mapping as part of the geology course. The Play (an annual event on RG's birthday) that year was “Lawrence and the Wetbacks”. William had sung a “talking blues” in it. Mati's film had a weak story line but shows various of the Deya characters at the time including, RG, Margot, Bill Waldren.
